questions.text: Suma, a 33-year-old lady, was diagnosed with pituitary microadenoma. In her second trimester, she developed visual disturbances, hypotension, and a headache. What is the visual defect experienced by this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Superio-temporal quadrantanopia

options.label: B
options.text: Ipsilateral homonymous hemianopia

options.label: C
options.text: Contralateral homonymous hemianopia

options.label: D
options.text: Heteronymous hemianopia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heteronymous hemianopia The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pituitary adenoma . The lesion almost always is associated with compression at the level of optic chiasma and causes heteronymous hemianopia (bitemporal hemianopia). Heteronymous hemianopia is the loss of half of the visual field on different sides in both eyes. It is separated into two categories: Binasal hemianopia: the loss of the fields surrounding the nose. Bitemporal hemianopia: the loss of the fields closest to the temples.

Highyeild:

Optic chiasma lesions Central -bitemporal hemianopia Pituitary adenoma -bitemporal superior quadrantanopia Craniopharyngioma -bitemporal inferior quadrantanopia Lateral -binasal hemianopia Proximal optic nerve injury causes junctional scotoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - A ,B and C are incorrect option. Option: A. Option: B is incorrect option because it will be seen in case of partial optic nerve damage . Option: C.

Extraedge:

The optic chiasma is a flattened structure 12 mm horizontally and 8mm anteroposteriorly , 4mm thick, ensheathed by pia mater and surrounded by CSF. lies over the diaphragma sellae, so visual field defects are seen in patients with pituitary tumour having suprasellar extension. The posterior chiasma continues with the optic tracts and form the anterior wall of the third ventricle.

questions.text: A child was taken to the Ophthalmology OPD by his parents because his class teacher suspected that he may need spectacles. After some tests, his distant vision was recorded as V = 6/12. His parents were anxious to know what it meant in order to understand the seriousness of the condition. What does 6/12 recorded mean, according to you?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that the child can see half of what a normal person sees

options.label: B
options.text: The child can see from 12 meters that a normal person sees from 6 meters

options.label: C
options.text: The child can see from 6 meters that a normal person sees from 12 meters

options.label: D
options.text: It means the child can read 6 letters clearly out of 12 letters

questions.correct_answer: C. The child can see from 6 meters that a normal person sees from 12 meters
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The child can see from 6 meters that a normal person sees from 12 meters The child can see from 6 metres that a normal person sees from 12 metres. V = 6/12; the numerator suggests the distance a normal person can read, i.e., 6 metres, and the denominator suggests the distance from which the patient can read clearly. In this case, it is 12 metres.

Highyeild:

The normal person's distant vision will hence be V = 6/6.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B and D. are incorrect

options.label: B
options.text: The letter H at the top subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a point 6 meters away from it

options.label: C
options.text: The person reading the line "A E L O H C T" clearly without any lens is considered to be normal

options.label: D
options.text: Each letter in the chart is shaped in such a way that the letters can be placed perfectly in a square

questions.correct_answer: B. The letter H at the top subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a point 6 meters away from it
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The letter H at the top subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a point 6 meters away from it The letter H at the top subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a distance of 60 metres from it (Not 6 metres) Those in the subsequent lines will subtend an angle of 5 minutes if they are at 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, and 6 metres from the eye.

Highyeild:

Each alphabet subtends an angle of 5 minutes at its respective distances mentioned just above the line . Hence the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a 60 metres distance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Snellens Chart is the most widely used chart to test distant vision in mainly literate people. It can either be evaluated in metres or even in feet. Option: C. The line A E L O H C T is the line that a normal person reads from a 6 metres mark. Hence, if the patient is able to read it clearly, his distant vision is considered to be normal. questions.text: The line at the 18-metres mark in the Snellen’s chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes at the point 18 metres distant from it. So what will be the angle subtended by the same line at a 6 -metre distant point?

options.label: A
options.text: 18 Minutes

options.label: B
options.text: 1.66 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: 50 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: 15 minutes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

15 minutes Visual acuity test - types consist of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. The breadth of the lines of which the letters are composed is such that the edges will subtend an angle of 1 minute at the nodal point of the eye at a particular distance. Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square , the sides of which are five times the breadth of the constituent lines. Hence, the whole letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

Highyeild:

The alphabets in the 18 metres line will subtend an angle of 15 minutes at a 6 metres distant point because Angle subtended by the line at 18 metres = 5 minutes Angle subtended by the line at 6 metres = 5 minutes * 18/6 = 15 minutes In simple words, the angle subtended by a specific line at a particular point is inversely proportional to the distance of that particular point.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B & C . are incorrect options.

Extraedge:

For example, If the distance decreases by three times , the angle subtended at that point increases by 3 times. So, angle subtended by each line at the 6 metre mark is as follows 60 m line = 5 *10 = 50 minutes 36 m line - 5 *6 = 30 minutes 18 m line - 5 *3 = 15 minutes 12 m line - 5 *2 = 10 minutes

questions.text: Place the following options given below in the descending order of the distant vision, i.e., from better vision to worst. Perception of light Hand movements Finger counting 1/60 Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: a - b - c - d

options.label: B
options.text: d - c - b - a

options.label: C
options.text: d - b - c - a

options.label: D
options.text: a - c - b – d

questions.explanation:
Solution:

d - c - b - a The correct order from better to worst is as follows: 1/60: Finger counting, hand movements, perception of light. If he cannot read the top letter at a distance of 1 metre, he is asked to count the fingers of the doctor, which are held at a distance of 1 metre from the patient. If the patient is able to count, it is recorded as "V = finger counting at 1 metre" . If he doesn't succeed in it , the doctor moves his hand in front of his face. If he can count the fingers now, the distant vision recorded is " V = Finger counting near face" . If he is unable to see movements , a light is focused on his ey e in a dark room and he is asked if he can perceive the light. If he is able to do it, V = PL + (perception of light-present +) If this is possible, he is asked for the projections of rays, where he is asked about the direction of the light, like superior, nasal, inferior, or temporal. It is recorded as accuracy, as perception of light alone cannot be relied on completely. And projection of rays adds to the confirmation of the vision.

Highyeild:

Snellen’s chart is the most widely used chart to test distant vision in mainly literate people. It can either be evaluated in metres or even in feet. Each alphabet subtends an angle of 5 minutes at its respective distances mentioned just above the line . Hence, the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a 60 metre distance.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, C & D . are not in correct order so they are incorrect option.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents to Ophthalmology Opd complaining of an inability to see distant objects clearly. He is asked to get his visual acuity checked. Which of the following is correct regarding visual acuity?

options.label: A
options.text: Each letter in Snellen chart subtends an angle of 1 minute

options.label: B
options.text: Two objects are appreciated as separate if two adjacent cones are stimulated

options.label: C
options.text: Foveal cones are separated by 2 microns

options.label: D
options.text: In decimal acuity, a higher visual acuity is represented by a numerically smaller number.

questions.correct_answer: D. In decimal acuity, a higher visual acuity is represented by a numerically smaller number.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In decimal acuity, a higher visual acuity is represented by a numerically smaller number. The Snellen fraction can be reduced to a decimal number, and it is known as decimal acuity. In this system, a higher visual acuity is represented by a numerically smaller number which is reversed in the Snellen grading. In the decimal system, acuity is defined as the reciprocal value of the size of the gap (measured in arc minutes) of the smallest Landolt C , the orientation of which can be reliably identified. A value of 1.0 is equal to 6/6. table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} FEET METRES DECIMEL 20/200 6/60 0.10 20/160 6/48 0.125 20/125 6/38 0.16 20/100 6/30 0.20 20/80 6/24 0.25 20/60 6/18 0.33 20/50 6/15 0.40 20/40 6/12 0.50 20/30 6/9 0.67 20/25 6/7.5 0.80 20/20 6/6 1.00

Highyeild:

Snellen’s chart is the most widely used chart to test distant vision in mainly literate people. It can either be evaluated in meters or even in feet. Each alphabet subtends an angle of 5 minutes at its respective distances mentioned just above the line . Hence, the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a 60 metre distance. The Snellen Chart uses a geometric scale to measure visual acuity, with normal vision at a distance being set at 20/20 or 6/6. The numerator represents the distance that the patient is standing from the chart (in feet), while the denominator represents the distance from which a person with perfect eyesight is still able to read the smallest line that the patient can clearly visualize. For example, a patient standing 20 feet or 6 metres away from the chart who can clearly read until the line of font that a person with normal visual acuity can read from 40 feet or 12 metres away would be measured as 20/40 or 6/12 vision.

Two objects are appreciated as separate if two adjacent cones are stimulated: If two objects are so close that two adjacent cones are stimulated, then they will appear as a single target. Therefore, there must be an unstimulated cone between stimulated ones to allow for the resolution of two targets or edges. Option C . Foveal cones are separated by 2 microns: In the foveal image, all cells are cones with a center-to-center spacing of 6±0.2 μm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents with decreased near vision in both eyes. Ocular examination is normal. His visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18, and in the left eye it is 6/12. Which of the following is incorrect regarding visual acuity?

options.label: A
options.text: Acuity of 6/12 corresponds to an MAR of 2 minutes of arc.

options.label: B
options.text: Acuity of 6/12 corresponds to log MAR of 0.3

options.label: C
options.text: In macular disorders, visual acuity improves through pinhole

options.label: D
options.text: V = 6/12 + 2 D = 6/6 indicates hypermetropia of 2D

questions.correct_answer: C. In macular disorders, visual acuity improves through pinhole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In macular disorders, visual acuity improves through pinhole If the vision is subnormal, as in this case, the visual acuity is again determined by asking the patient to read the letters through a pinhole . If it improves, it indicates an underlying refractive error . Pinhole may worsen vision in case of macular disease.

Highyeild:

Pinholes may worsen vision in cases of macular disease. If the vision is subnormal, the visual acuity is again determined by asking the patient to read the letters through a pinhole . If it improves, it indicates an underlying refractive error.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is calculated by dividing the denominator by the distance at which the letters were read. For example, a Snellen acuity of 6/12 corresponds to an MAR of 2 minutes of arc . Option: B. The log MAR, or a logarithm of the MAR , allows for constant geometric progression over each step, and a Snellen acuity of 6/12 or a MAR of 2 minutes of arc corresponds to a log MAR of 0.3 as the base 10-logarithm of 2 is 0.3. Option: D. The refraction of the eye must be determined, and the visual acuity should be assessed with correcting glasses in place. If there are two dioptres of hypermetropia , the best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) is written as: V = 6/12 + 2 D = 6/6.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with decreased far vision in her right eye. Ocular examination is normal. His visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18 and in the left eye is 6/6. Which of the following is incorrect regarding visual acuity?

options.label: A

options.text: V = 6/12 + 2 d = 6/6 indicates myopia of 2d

options.label: C
options.text: Each letter in snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minute

options.label: D
options.text: Acuity of 6/12 corresponds to an mar of 2 minutes of arc.

questions.correct_answer: B. V = 6/12 + 2 d = 6/6 indicates myopia of 2d
questions.explanation:
Solution:

V = 6/12 + 2 d = 6/6 indicates myopia of 2d Best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) is calculated using refraction of the eye and visual acuity with correcting glasses in place. BCVA of V = 6/12 + 2 D = 6/6 indicates two dioptres of hypermetropia , and not myopia, in which case it will be written as 6/12 - 2 D = 6/6.

Highyeild:

Snellen’s chart is the most widely used chart to test distant vision in mainly literate people. It can either be evaluated in meters or even in feet. In Snellen’s chart , one whole letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance. For example, the largest letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point if it is 60 m from the eye. Each alphabet subtends an angle of 5 minutes at its respective distances mentioned just above the line . Hence, the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a 60 metre distance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The log MAR, or a logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution , allows for constant geometric progression over each step and a Snellen acuity of 6/12 or MAR of 2 minutes of arc corresponds to a log MAR of 0.3 as base 10-logarithm of 2 is 0.3. Option: C. In the Snellen chart , one whole letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance. For example, the largest letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point if it is 60 m from the eye. Option: D. minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is calculated by dividing the denominator by the distance at which the letters were read. For example, a Snellen acuity of 6/12 corresponds to an MAR of 2 minutes of arc.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with diminution of vision in both eyes. His visual acuity is recorded as V = PL and projection of light is accurate in each quadrant. Which of the following is correct regarding visual acuity in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Counting fingers is at 1m

options.label: B
options.text: PL indicates projection of light

options.label: C
options.text: Improvement in visual acuity through pinhole would indicate a macular disorder.

options.label: D
options.text: In projection of light, light is directed from four directions

questions.correct_answer: D. In projection of light, light is directed from four directions
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In projection of light, light is directed from four directions If a patient is able to perceive light (i.e., V = PL), he may be able to give some indication of the four directions in which the light is directed —up, down, right, and left. This is recorded as a projection of light, accurate or inaccurate, in each quadrant.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. V = PL indicates the perception of light present. If a patient is unable to see hand movements, he is taken into the dark room and a light is focused on his eye, and he is asked to say when the light is on and when it is off. If he succeeds in doing this, visual acuity is noted as PL. Option: B. PL indicates perception of light, which is tested if a patient is unable to see hand movements. Option: C. If the vision is subnormal, as in this case, the visual acuity is again determined by asking the patient to read the letters through a pinhole. If it improves, it indicates an underlying refractive error. Pinholes may worsen vision in cases of macular disease.

Extraedge:

The minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is calculated by dividing the denominator by the distance at which the letters were read. For example, a Snellen acuity of 6/12 corresponds to an MAR of 2 minutes of arc.

questions.text: A 1-year-old presents to the ophthalmology out patient department with a squint in the right eye. On examination, there is right sided esotropia. The visual acuity of the child needs to be tested. Which of the following tests can be used?

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiff Acuity Cards

options.label: B
options.text: Fook’s symbol test

options.label: C
options.text: Visual evoked potential

options.label: D
options.text: All the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above There are two main techniques to measure visual acuity in children: the pattern of visual evoked potential (VEP) and preferential looking behaviour . The VEP test proves more successful and confirms more closely to the findings of Snellen and ‘E’ acuity testing . Other test types include the Keeler–Elliott and Kay picture test, Cardiff acuity cards, Ffooks symbols, preferential looking test.

Highyeild:

The charts which can be used for young children among the options are Cardiff Acuity charts Keeler Elliott Picture Test Preferential looking test Some other methods that can be used for children and infants include Ffooks Symbols Teller Acuity Testing Patterned VEP Cardiff acuity cards

questions.text: A 2-years-old child presents with a left eye squint. On examination, there is right sided exotropia. Teller acuity test was used to test the visual acuity here. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this test?

options.label: A
options.text: This test is used for children aged 1 to 3 years

options.label: B
options.text: It consists of 27 cards

options.label: C
options.text: Half set consists of vertical black and white bars

options.label: D
options.text: Half set has a uniform grey background

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It consists of 27 cards The Teller acuity card system consists of 17 cards, and not 27. The teller cards are presented in the centre of a large grey ‘stage ’, after first drawing attention to the stage with a toy. There is a small hole in the centre of each card , through which the examiner judges the preferred side of the card by noting the infant’s fixation.

Highyeild:

If the infant fixes on the side of the card with the grating, a smaller grating size is shown until no preference for fixation is observed. The grating size (spatial frequency) of the card can then be converted to the equivalent of the Snellen chart.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D : Teller acuity test is used in very young, preverbal children, ( 1−3 years of age). The Teller acuity card system consists of 17 cards, one half is a set of vertical black-and-white bars of varying width and spatial frequency, and the other half has a uniform grey background.

questions.correct_answer: C. The child is evaluated to have a distant vision recorded as 6/18
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The child is evaluated to have a distant vision recorded as 6/18 The child reading up to the 18-metre line is evaluated to have a distant vision of 6/18, which is considered a defective vision . The normal vision will be 6/6 in Snellen’s chart . The patient will have his distant vision as V = 6/18 .

In Snellen chart , one whole letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance. For example, the largest letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point if it is 60 m from the eye. Each alphabet subtends an angle of 5 minutes at its respective distances mentioned just above the line . Hence the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes at a 60 metre distance.

These consist of a series of letters arranged in lines decreasing in size. One example is the Snellen’s chart given in the image. Option: D .
